question_stem: A particle P moves along a straight line. Its displacement, \(s\) metres, from a fixed point O at time \(t\) seconds is given by \(s = t^2 - 2t + 9\).  The particle is more than 10 metres from O.

parts.question_text: Find the set of possible values of \(t\).
parts.solution_text:
The particle is more than 10 metres from O, so \(|s| > 10\).  This gives two inequalities:

1. \(s > 10\):
\(t^2 - 2t + 9 > 10\)
\(t^2 - 2t - 1 > 0\)
Using the quadratic formula, \(t = \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2 - 4(1)(-1)}}{2(1)} = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{8}}{2} = 1 \pm \sqrt{2}\)
So \(t > 1 + \sqrt{2}\) or \(t < 1 - \sqrt{2}\)

2. \(s < -10\):
\(t^2 - 2t + 9 < -10\)
\(t^2 - 2t + 19 < 0\)
The discriminant is \((-2)^2 - 4(1)(19) = 4 - 76 = -72 < 0\). Since the coefficient of \(t^2\) is positive, the quadratic is always positive, meaning there are no real solutions to this inequality.

Therefore, combining the solutions from both cases, the set of possible values for \(t\) is \(t > 1 + \sqrt{2}\) or \(t < 1 - \sqrt{2}\).
